bunpro.meaning: But, Although, If only, I wish I had
bunpro.writeup: ものをis a grammar point that functions in a similar way to のに in that it will express that (A) is something that was desired, despite (B) being the actual result. However, it is primarily used when the speaker is trying to convey their displeasure at the result of (B), due to (A) being something that by all means should have happened.ものをwill be translated as 'if only (A)', or '(A), but (B)'. Despite being a construction of もの and theadverbial particleを,ものをis often considered as a standaloneconjunction particle. It can be seen following verbs or い-Adjectives in theirstandard form, or な-Adjectives followed by な.As can be seen in the above examples,ものをis almost always preceded by hypothetical structures such as ば at some point leading up to its use.Cautionものをwill often be seen at the end of sentences, with what would have come after it being left unspoken. In these cases, the important information is still there, as the (A) part of the sentence will always highlight what the ideal result was. Because of this, it can be safely assumed that the speaker is just frustrated that (A) didn't happen.Fun FactTheadverbial particleを is often used this way in Japanese, where no specific action is linked to it. In these situations it usually just indicates an ideal or goal to which the method of achieving it (the verb that would usually be attached to を) is omitted. ものを can be thought of as an extension of this in literally meaning 'to that which was (A)', with 'I wish it had happened' being unsaid.

examples.japanese: もっと早くに歯医者に行けば歯を抜かずに済んだものを...
examples.english: If you went to the dentist earlier, they wouldn't have had to remove your tooth, but…

examples.japanese: 目を合わせなかったら止められなかったものを、なんで警察なんかと目を合わせちゃうんだ。
examples.english: If only you didn't make eye contact with the police, we wouldn't have been stopped, so why did you have to go and make eye contact with them?

examples.japanese: アレルギーなどがあったなら、さきに言ってくれればいいものを...
examples.english: If you had an allergy, you should have let me know beforehand, but…

examples.japanese: 「手伝って」って言えばいいものを、一人でやるからこう言う目に会うんだよ。
examples.english: If you have just asked for help, but because you did it alone, it ended up like this.

examples.japanese: みんなでやれば簡単なものを...
examples.english: It would have been easy if we all worked on it together, but…

examples.japanese: 道具を使えば楽なものを、わざわざ自分の力でやろうとするから怪我をするんだよ。
examples.english: It would have been easier if you used tools, but because you went out of your way to try it without any tools, you ended up getting hurt.

examples.japanese: 素直に認めていればいいものを...
examples.english: I should have just been honest, but… (I should have just been honest, but instead I continued to lie)

examples.japanese: 政治ポスター：日本を前へ。
examples.english: Political poster: Japan forward. (Verb omitted but obvious from context, the positive improvement of Japan)

examples.japanese: かみやま：「その不良学生が僕の鉛筆を食わなかったら入学試験を受けていたはずのもんを...(食ったから、受けられなかった)」
examples.english: Kamiyama: 'If that delinquent hadn't eaten my pencil, I would have taken the school entrance exam for sure, but… (He has eaten it, so I couldn't)'

examples.japanese: 犯罪コメディ映画、トニー：「まったく、ボリス、おとなしく死んでおればいいものを...」
examples.english: Crime comedy movie, Tony: 'Dear God, Boris, it would have been good if you had just shut up and died, but…'

examples.japanese: 「もっと早くタバコをやめれば健康問題なしに済んだものを、手遅れになってしまった。」
examples.english: 'If I had quit smoking much earlier I would have ended up without any health problems, but now it is too late.'

examples.japanese: 父は息子に言う：「RINEでメッセージをしてくれたら迎えに行ってあげたもんを...
examples.english: Father speaking to his son: 'If you had messaged me on Rine, I would have picked you up, but… (you didn't).'

examples.japanese: 「彼が君に謝ったのなら許すべきものを、子供じゃあるまいし、無視するなんてひどすぎるよ。」
examples.english: 'You are not a child! If he is apologizing, you should forgive him, but ignoring him is too cruel!'

dojg.description: A disjunctive coordinate conjunction expressing the meaning of “although” with the speaker’s strong feeling of discontent

examples.japanese: (ksa).彼は日本語を続けて勉強すればいいものを、1年間やっただけでやめてしまった。
examples.english: Although he should have continued studying Japanese, he quit  after only one year.

examples.japanese: (ksb).すぐ医者に診てもらったら簡単に治っていたものを、手遅れになってしまった。
examples.english: Had I gone to the doctor right away, I would have gotten better  easily, but I acted too late.

examples.japanese: (a).ゴルフかなんかして少しリラックスすればいいものを、父は週末でも会社の仕事を家でやっている。
examples.english: My father should play golf or something and relax a little bit,  but he brings work home from the ofﬁce even on weekends.

examples.japanese: (b).あのくだらない小説はちょっと読んだだけでやめればよかったものを、なんと最後まで読んでしまった。全くの時間の浪費だった。
examples.english: I should have stopped reading that cheap  novel after a few pages, but believe it or not, I read it  to the very end. It was an utter waste of time.

examples.japanese: (c).居留守を使えばいいものを、彼女は気が弱いのでそうもできず、いやいや人に会うことになってしまうのだ。
examples.english: She doesn't have to answer the door, but she doesn't have the  nerve to resist and ends up talking to people even though she doesn't want to.

examples.japanese: (d).私のことが嫌いなら嫌いだともっと早くはっきり言ってくれたらよかったものを。
examples.english: He should have told me much earlier that he didn't like me (literally:  if in fact he didn't like me).

examples.japanese: (e).時間があったらいろいろな外国旅行ができたものを、いつも忙しく働いてきたので、外国はどこにも行っていない。
examples.english: Had I the time, I could have made trips to  various foreign countries, but because I've been so  busy working I have never been overseas.

examples.japanese: (f).父があと1年生きていてくれたら私の結婚式に出てもらえたものを、私がぐずぐずしていたばかりに、父に私の晴れ姿を見てもらえず、とても残念です。
examples.english: Had my father lived one year longer, he could have attended my  wedding ceremony, but just because I was indecisive for so long, I couldn't  give him the chance to see me in my wedding dress. I feel so sorry!
